meanings.definition: To insert punctuation marks in written text.
meanings.sent1: She always remembers to punctuate her sentences with periods.
meanings.sent2: It is important to punctuate your writing correctly to make it clear.
meanings.sent3: The teacher asked the students to punctuate the paragraph with commas, but they used exclamation marks instead!
meanings.sent4: His laughter punctuated the silence in the room like an unexpected exclamation point.
meanings.sent5: The sound of the clock ticking helped punctuate the tense atmosphere in the waiting room.

meanings.definition: To interrupt or emphasize something with punctuation.
meanings.sent1: The sudden thunderstorm punctuated their picnic with dashes of rain.
meanings.sent2: Her speech was punctuated by long pauses for dramatic effect.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to punctuate the quiet with its meows, demanding attention.
meanings.sent4: The bright fireworks punctuated the night sky like colorful exclamation marks.
meanings.sent5: The drumbeats punctuated the song, adding a rhythmic emphasis to the music.

meanings.sent1: The streetlights punctuate the road, providing light at regular intervals.
meanings.sent2: The chirping of crickets punctuated the stillness of the night.
meanings.sent3: The smell of fresh bread punctuated the air every morning, signaling the start of a new day.
meanings.sent4: The cheers from the crowd punctuated the silence of the stadium, echoing in waves.
meanings.sent5: The sound of the train whistle punctuated the quiet countryside, breaking the peace momentarily.
